content: as charted to the last stitch move the first stitch from the sole to the instep work the last 2 stitches as charted on the sole k all stitches © mary pat mcgurk 2023 v 1 5 6 continue to work remaining charted rounds as set in rounds 4 and 5 until 12 stitches remain on each needle on completing a row 23 27 31 cut the yarn graft stitches together additional short toe options after working the first decrease rounds 4 and 5 continue to work remaining rounds as set with option to end decreases after any odd numbered round making that a knit round graft stitches together palestrina knots there are 7 leg/instep 3-stitch cluster columns only the first four clusters beneath the cuff are embroidered with palestrina knots this is done with the cc2 yarn knot placement is charted setting between the small holes formed earlier from working the 3-stitch clusters instructions specific to the gathering socks design are provided below as noted at the beginning of the pattern notes it is beneficial to do the embroidery before closing the toes images of the rs and ws of the embroidered knots are provided in the glossary for those not familiar with the embroidery technique this link offers a clear presentation of how to create the knots https //youtu be/kgk3vzc_l4e it is worth viewing to understand how the knots are created the demonstration shows how a thread would be carried along the rs between knots knitters of the gathering socks must carry the connecting yarn along the ws how to embroider the palestrina knots for the gathering socks 1 cut 1 yd 9 m length of cc2 thread on a blunt tipped tapestry or embroidery needle 2 with the front of sock facing the knitter cuff at top/toe at bottom turn the cuff to the left the designer s knots were created working left to right same direction as shown in the video left-handed knitters may find it easier to turn the cuff to the right then working right to left 3 enter from behind then through the front the first row below first 3-stitch cluster then diagonally down into the fabric 2 row below and then up to the rs pass up and under the diagonal stitch to create the two arms pass the yarn under the top arm over the working thread and pull through snugly but not too tightly to create the first palestrina knot the knot should lie between the cluster holes above and below do not carry the yarn along the rs the working yarn secures the knot by entering the fabric into or alongside the edge of the knot just formed it is recommended to invisibly stabilize the knot weaving a single stitch beneath the area covered with the knot do not cut the yarn carry the yarn along the ws of the fabric to the point that the yarn once again enters to the fabric s rs just to the edge
